Overall, the responses of governments and educational institutions in developing countries to the challenges posed by the pandemic were characterized by a combination of policy measures, technological interventions, and support initiatives. While some countries were able to implement relatively effective measures to maintain educational continuity, others faced significant challenges in addressing the disparities exacerbated by the pandemic. The paper "A Resilient ICT4D Approach to ECO Countries' Education Response during COVID-19 Pandemic" [8] emphasizes the importance of investing in digital infrastructure and improving digital literacy to ensure that all students have access to quality education, even in times of crisis. The paper also highlights the need for sustained investment in education to address the long-term challenges of remote learning and to build more resilient educational systems.

content.heading: 2.8 Role of Technology in Mitigating Disruptions
content.content:
The role of technology in mitigating the impact of the pandemic on education has been significant, especially in developing countries where traditional educational infrastructure was already limited. The sudden transition to remote learning necessitated the adoption of various digital solutions, including online learning platforms, mobile applications, and other technological innovations, to ensure continuity in education. These technologies were not only critical in bridging the gap caused by school closures but also in addressing issues of access, equity, and quality of education.

One of the most notable contributions of technology during the pandemic was the rapid adoption of online learning platforms. These platforms enabled students and teachers to continue their educational activities despite the physical restrictions imposed by the pandemic. For instance, the paper titled "Cloud Computing-based Higher Education Platforms during the COVID-19 Pandemic" highlights the role of cloud computing in supporting online teaching during the pandemic, with a focus on the implementation of cloud-based education platforms in Chinese universities [19]. The study found that these platforms played a crucial role in maintaining educational continuity and improving the efficiency of remote learning.

Mobile applications also emerged as a vital tool in mitigating the disruptions caused by the pandemic. In particular, mobile learning (m-learning) provided an accessible and flexible solution for students in resource-constrained environments. The paper titled "Leveraging Mobile Learning Platforms for Flexible Education Delivery: Bridging Educational Gaps in Afghanistan" underscores the potential of mobile learning in addressing the challenges faced by students in Afghanistan, where infrastructure and access to traditional educational resources are limited [11]. The study highlights how mobile learning platforms can provide an alternative to conventional classroom learning, especially in regions with limited access to high-speed internet and digital devices.

Beyond online learning platforms and mobile applications, other digital solutions such as virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) were also explored to enhance the remote learning experience. The paper titled "Virtual Reality Photo-based Tours for Teaching Filipino Vocabulary in an Online Class in Japan: Transitioning into the New Normal" describes the use of VR-based interventions to support language learning in an online setting [50]. The study found that VR technology enhanced student engagement and improved the overall learning experience, even in a remote environment.

Moreover, the use of artificial intelligence (AI) and generative AI models has shown promise in supporting remote learning. For example, the paper titled "Predicting Stress in Remote Learning via Advanced Deep Learning Technologies" explores the potential of machine learning models to monitor student mental states and improve remote teaching [51]. AI-driven tools have been instrumental in providing personalized learning experiences, adapting to the needs of individual students, and improving the efficiency of remote instruction.

Another significant technological innovation that played a role in mitigating educational disruptions was the use of tele-education and broadcast-based learning. In countries with limited digital infrastructure, radio and television broadcasts were used to deliver educational content to students. The paper titled "Distance Learning in Primary School During the COVID-19 Pandemic: Results of the SMART KIDS Experiment" discusses the implementation of distance learning using electronic educational resources (EER) and virtual classrooms in Ukraine [52]. The study highlights the importance of providing teachers and students with the necessary technological resources to ensure the effective implementation of remote learning.

The role of technology in mitigating the impact of the pandemic on education also extended to the development of secure and transparent educational systems. Blockchain technology was explored as a solution for ensuring the integrity of educational records and digital credentials. The paper titled "Blockchain for Secure and Transparent Education Systems" discusses the potential of blockchain in addressing issues related to the security and reliability of educational data [53]. The study suggests that blockchain can provide a robust solution for maintaining the authenticity of educational records, especially in contexts with limited institutional trust.

In addition to these specific technologies, the broader adoption of digital tools and platforms has contributed to the transformation of the educational landscape. The paper titled "Investigating the impact of COVID-19 on Online Learning-based Web Behavior" analyzes the shift in online learning behaviors during the pandemic and highlights the increased reliance on digital tools and platforms [46]. The study found that the pandemic accelerated the adoption of online learning technologies, with a significant increase in the use of digital tools for education.

However, the implementation of these technological solutions also presented challenges. The paper titled "Challenges in Implementing AI and Smart Technologies in Education" discusses the barriers to adopting AI and smart technologies in developing countries, including inadequate infrastructure, limited digital literacy, and the need for sustainable funding and policy support [17]. The study emphasizes the importance of addressing these challenges to ensure the effective integration of technology into the education system.

Overall, the role of technology in mitigating the impact of the pandemic on education has been multifaceted and essential. From online learning platforms and mobile applications to AI-driven solutions and tele-education, technology has played a crucial role in maintaining educational continuity and addressing the challenges posed by the pandemic. While the implementation of these technologies has presented certain challenges, the lessons learned from this period provide valuable insights for the future of education in developing countries. As the education sector continues to evolve, the integration of technology will remain a key factor in ensuring equitable access to quality education for all students.

content.heading: 2.9 Long-term Implications for Education
content.content:
The long-term implications of the COVID-19 pandemic on education in developing countries are profound and multifaceted, with far-reaching consequences that extend beyond the immediate disruption caused by school closures and the shift to remote learning. The pandemic has underscored the fragility of existing educational systems, exposing long-standing inequalities and highlighting the urgent need for systemic reforms. One of the most significant long-term implications is the necessity for improved digital infrastructure. As the pandemic has demonstrated, the absence of reliable internet access, digital devices, and adequate technological resources has severely limited the ability of students in developing countries to engage in remote learning. For instance, studies have shown that in many regions, students from low-income families face significant barriers to accessing online education due to a lack of digital devices and stable internet connections [54]. This digital divide has not only exacerbated existing educational inequalities but has also revealed the urgent need for investments in digital infrastructure to ensure equitable access to education in the future.

Moreover, the pandemic has underscored the importance of building more resilient educational systems that can withstand future crises. The abrupt shift to remote learning has revealed the limitations of traditional educational models, which are often ill-equipped to handle large-scale disruptions. In many developing countries, the transition to remote learning was haphazard and poorly supported, with inadequate training for teachers and limited resources for students [10]. This has highlighted the need for educational systems that are more flexible and adaptable, capable of quickly responding to changing circumstances. The development of resilient educational systems requires not only investment in digital infrastructure but also a rethinking of pedagogical approaches and curriculum design to accommodate diverse learning environments.

Another critical long-term implication is the potential for technological innovations to reshape the educational landscape in developing countries. The pandemic has accelerated the adoption of digital tools and platforms, such as online learning systems, mobile applications, and virtual classrooms. These technologies have the potential to enhance access to education, improve learning outcomes, and provide more personalized learning experiences. For example, the use of generative AI models like ChatGPT and GPT-4 has shown promise in supporting language learning, content creation, and personalized assistance for students and educators [55]. However, the integration of such technologies into educational systems in developing countries faces significant challenges, including a lack of digital literacy, inadequate infrastructure, and limited access to trained educators. Addressing these challenges requires a coordinated effort involving governments, educational institutions, and the private sector to develop strategies that promote equitable access to and effective use of digital technologies in education.

The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of addressing socioeconomic disparities in education. The disruption of traditional learning environments has disproportionately affected students from marginalized and vulnerable populations, including those in rural areas, low-income families, and students with disabilities [5]. These groups often lack the resources and support needed to participate in remote learning, leading to increased educational inequality. The long-term implications of this crisis include the need for targeted interventions to support these vulnerable populations, such as providing access to digital devices, expanding internet connectivity, and offering additional academic and psychological support. For example, the implementation of mobile learning platforms in Afghanistan has been identified as a potential solution to bridge educational gaps in regions with limited infrastructure and resources [11]. These initiatives can help ensure that all students have the opportunity to benefit from educational technologies, regardless of their socioeconomic background.

In addition to addressing immediate challenges, the pandemic has prompted a reevaluation of the role of technology in education. The rapid adoption of digital tools during the pandemic has demonstrated their potential to enhance teaching and learning, but it has also raised concerns about the digital divide and the need for inclusive educational policies. The integration of technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), the Internet of Things (IoT), and blockchain has the potential to transform education by improving access, enhancing efficiency, and promoting transparency. For instance, AI-driven platforms can provide personalized learning experiences tailored to the needs of individual students, while blockchain can ensure the security and integrity of educational records [56]. However, the successful implementation of these technologies in developing countries requires a focus on digital literacy, infrastructure development, and the creation of supportive policy frameworks.

The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of teacher training and support in the context of digital education. The shift to remote learning has placed additional demands on educators, who must adapt to new technologies and pedagogical approaches. This has underscored the need for comprehensive teacher training programs that equip educators with the skills and knowledge needed to effectively implement digital learning tools. In addition, the pandemic has revealed the importance of mental health and well-being for both students and educators, further emphasizing the need for holistic support systems that address the emotional and psychological challenges of remote learning.

In conclusion, the long-term implications of the pandemic on education in developing countries are significant and far-reaching. The need for improved digital infrastructure, more resilient educational systems, and targeted interventions to address socioeconomic disparities is clear. The integration of technological innovations, the development of inclusive educational policies, and the provision of teacher training and support are essential components of a comprehensive response. By addressing these challenges, developing countries can build more equitable, resilient, and effective educational systems that are better prepared to meet the needs of all learners in the post-pandemic era.

content.heading: 3.1 AI in Remote Learning and Personalized Education
content.content:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a transformative force in the realm of remote learning and personalized education, particularly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. The sudden shift to remote education has necessitated innovative solutions to maintain educational continuity, and AI has played a pivotal role in this transformation. AI-powered tutoring systems and adaptive learning platforms have enabled educators to provide tailored learning experiences to students, addressing the unique needs of each learner. These technologies not only help in mitigating the challenges of remote education but also enhance the overall effectiveness of the learning process.

One of the key applications of AI in remote learning is the development of AI-powered tutoring systems. These systems utilize machine learning algorithms to analyze student performance data and provide personalized feedback and guidance. For instance, platforms like Knewton and DreamBox Learning employ AI to adapt to the learning pace and style of individual students, offering customized content and exercises. Such systems can identify areas where a student is struggling and provide targeted interventions, thereby enhancing the learning outcomes. The effectiveness of these systems is supported by research that highlights the benefits of personalized learning in improving student engagement and academic performance [57].

Another significant application of AI in remote learning is the use of adaptive learning platforms. These platforms leverage AI to create dynamic learning environments that adjust to the needs of the students in real-time. For example, platforms like Coursera and Khan Academy use AI to recommend relevant courses and resources based on the learner's progress and interests. This adaptive approach ensures that students receive the most appropriate content at the right time, thereby optimizing their learning experience. The adaptability of these platforms is crucial in addressing the diverse needs of students, especially in developing countries where access to quality education is often limited [57].

AI also plays a crucial role in the development of intelligent educational assistants, which can provide 24/7 support to students. These assistants can answer questions, provide explanations, and offer guidance on various subjects. For instance, chatbots like IBM's Watson Assistant and Google's Meena have been integrated into educational platforms to enhance the student experience. These AI-driven assistants can handle a wide range of queries, from basic subject matter to complex problem-solving, thereby reducing the burden on educators and providing students with immediate support [57].

Moreover, AI has been instrumental in the development of predictive analytics tools that help educators understand student behavior and predict potential issues. These tools can analyze data from learning management systems (LMS) to identify students who may be at risk of falling behind. By detecting early warning signs, educators can intervene proactively to support struggling students. For example, the use of AI in platforms like Blackboard and Moodle has enabled institutions to monitor student performance and provide timely interventions. This data-driven approach is essential in ensuring that all students have the opportunity to succeed, regardless of their background or circumstances [57].

The integration of AI in remote learning has also facilitated the creation of immersive and interactive learning experiences. Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) technologies, powered by AI, have been used to create engaging educational content that enhances student understanding and retention. For instance, platforms like Labster and zSpace use AI to simulate real-world scenarios, allowing students to practice and apply their knowledge in a safe and controlled environment. These technologies are particularly beneficial for STEM education, where hands-on experience is crucial for learning [57].

In addition to these applications, AI has been used to support language learning and cultural exchange. AI-powered language learning platforms like Duolingo and Babbel utilize machine learning algorithms to provide personalized language instruction. These platforms can adapt to the learner's proficiency level and provide targeted exercises and feedback. The integration of AI in language learning has made it more accessible and effective, especially for students in developing countries who may not have access to native speakers or immersive language environments [57].

The role of AI in remote learning is further underscored by its ability to support educators in managing large classes and providing individualized attention. AI-driven tools can automate administrative tasks, such as grading and scheduling, allowing educators to focus more on teaching and student engagement. For example, platforms like Gradescope use AI to streamline the grading process, providing consistent and accurate feedback to students. This not only saves time but also ensures that students receive timely and relevant feedback, which is essential for their learning and development [57].

Despite the numerous benefits of AI in remote learning, there are challenges that need to be addressed. One of the primary concerns is the digital divide, where students in developing countries may lack access to the necessary technology and internet infrastructure. This can hinder the effective implementation of AI-driven educational solutions. Additionally, there are concerns about data privacy and security, as the use of AI in education involves the collection and analysis of large amounts of student data [57].

In conclusion, AI has revolutionized the landscape of remote learning and personalized education, offering innovative solutions to the challenges posed by the pandemic. The development of AI-powered tutoring systems, adaptive learning platforms, intelligent educational assistants, and predictive analytics tools has enhanced the learning experience for students. However, it is essential to address the challenges associated with AI in education, such as the digital divide and data privacy, to ensure that all students can benefit from these technological advancements. As the field of AI continues to evolve, its potential to transform education and improve learning outcomes remains immense.

content.heading: 3.2 Generative AI and Its Applications in Education
content.content:
Generative AI, particularly large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT and GPT-4, has emerged as a transformative force in the realm of education. These models, built on vast amounts of textual data, have the capacity to understand, generate, and manipulate human language with remarkable proficiency. Their potential applications in education span a wide spectrum, from language learning to content creation and personalized assistance for both students and educators. As the world grapples with the challenges of the post-pandemic educational landscape, the integration of generative AI into the educational framework has become increasingly relevant, especially in developing countries where access to quality education and resources remains a significant challenge [56].

In the context of language learning, generative AI models offer a promising avenue for students to enhance their linguistic skills. Traditional language learning methods often lack the interactive and personalized elements that can make the process engaging and effective. LLMs, however, can simulate real-time conversations, provide instant feedback, and adapt to the learner's pace and proficiency level. For instance, the use of AI-powered tutoring systems allows students to practice speaking and writing in a low-pressure environment, receiving immediate corrections and suggestions for improvement [27]. This is particularly beneficial in developing countries where access to native speakers and quality language instruction is limited. A study conducted in Chinese higher education institutions found that the integration of AI-driven language learning tools significantly improved students' engagement and language acquisition [7].

Content creation is another area where generative AI has made significant strides. Educators often face the challenge of producing high-quality, engaging, and culturally relevant materials for their students. LLMs can assist in generating lesson plans, quizzes, and even entire courses, thereby reducing the burden on teachers and allowing them to focus on more critical aspects of teaching. This is especially important in developing countries where educational resources are scarce and teachers may lack the time or expertise to create comprehensive materials. A study on the use of AI in the development of educational content highlighted that the use of AI can significantly reduce the time and effort required to create personalized learning materials, thereby enhancing the overall learning experience [56].

Moreover, generative AI can provide personalized assistance to both students and educators, addressing the unique needs and challenges of each individual. For students, AI can offer tailored learning experiences, adapting to their learning styles and providing targeted support. This can be particularly beneficial for students with diverse learning needs, including those with disabilities or those who are non-native speakers. A case study conducted in India demonstrated that the use of AI-powered learning platforms led to improved academic performance and increased student satisfaction [58]. For educators, AI can offer support in managing administrative tasks, providing insights into student performance, and facilitating personalized feedback. This can free up valuable time for teachers to focus on more meaningful interactions with their students.

The potential of generative AI in education extends beyond individual applications. It can also play a crucial role in addressing broader educational challenges, such as the digital divide and the lack of access to quality education. In developing countries, where infrastructure and resources are often limited, AI can help bridge the gap by providing accessible and affordable educational solutions. For instance, AI-powered mobile learning applications have been used to deliver educational content to students in remote and underserved areas, ensuring that they have access to quality education despite the limitations of their environment [59]. This is particularly relevant in the context of the pandemic, where the sudden shift to remote learning highlighted the need for adaptable and accessible educational tools.

However, the integration of generative AI in education is not without its challenges. Issues such as data privacy, ethical considerations, and the potential for misuse must be carefully addressed. The use of AI in education raises questions about the accuracy and reliability of the generated content, as well as the potential for biases in the training data. It is essential to ensure that AI systems are transparent, accountable, and aligned with ethical standards to prevent any adverse effects on students and educators. A study on the use of AI in education emphasized the importance of developing robust frameworks to govern the use of AI in educational settings, ensuring that it is used to enhance, rather than replace, the human elements of teaching [56].

In conclusion, generative AI represents a powerful tool that has the potential to revolutionize education in developing countries. By supporting language learning, content creation, and personalized assistance, AI can help address the unique challenges faced by these regions. However, the successful integration of AI in education requires careful consideration of ethical, technical, and social factors. As the educational landscape continues to evolve, the role of generative AI will likely become even more prominent, offering new opportunities for innovation and improvement in the delivery of education.

content.heading: 3.3 Mobile Learning and m-Learning Platforms
content.content:
Mobile learning (m-learning) has emerged as a critical solution for delivering education in resource-constrained environments, particularly in developing countries. This form of learning utilizes mobile devices such as smartphones, tablets, and other portable technologies to facilitate access to educational content, making it an attractive option where traditional infrastructure is lacking. The role of mobile learning applications in delivering education has gained significant attention due to their accessibility, convenience, and potential to improve student engagement and learning outcomes. This subsection explores the multifaceted role of mobile learning and m-learning platforms in addressing educational challenges, supported by empirical insights from relevant studies.

One of the most significant advantages of mobile learning is its accessibility. In many developing countries, access to computers and stable internet connections is limited, but mobile phone penetration is often high. According to a study on mobile learning in Afghanistan, mobile learning platforms have the potential to bridge educational gaps by leveraging the widespread use of mobile devices [11]. The study highlights that mobile learning can be particularly effective in regions where traditional educational infrastructure is lacking, providing students with a flexible and accessible mode of learning. This aligns with the findings of another study that emphasizes the importance of mobile technologies in reaching underserved populations, especially in rural and remote areas [60].

Convenience is another critical aspect of mobile learning. The portability of mobile devices allows students to access educational content anytime and anywhere, making it an ideal solution for learners who may face logistical challenges in attending traditional schools. A study on mobile learning in developing countries underscores that the convenience of mobile learning platforms enables students to engage with educational materials in a manner that fits their schedules and learning paces [11]. This flexibility is particularly beneficial for students who may need to balance education with other responsibilities, such as work or family commitments. Additionally, mobile learning platforms can provide personalized learning experiences, adapting to the specific needs and learning styles of individual students.

The impact of mobile learning on student engagement and learning outcomes is another area of focus. Research indicates that mobile learning can significantly enhance student engagement by offering interactive and multimedia-rich content. For instance, a study on mobile learning in Afghanistan highlights that mobile applications can make learning more interactive and engaging, which can lead to improved academic performance [11]. The use of mobile learning platforms can also facilitate immediate feedback, allowing students to track their progress and identify areas for improvement. This is particularly important in resource-constrained environments where access to teachers and educational support may be limited.

Moreover, mobile learning platforms have the potential to address some of the socio-economic disparities that hinder educational access. A study on the impact of mobile learning in developing countries notes that these platforms can provide equal access to educational resources, regardless of a student's socioeconomic background [11]. This is crucial in addressing the educational inequalities that often persist in developing countries, where students from low-income families may not have access to the same educational opportunities as their more affluent peers.

However, the implementation of mobile learning platforms in developing countries is not without challenges. One of the primary barriers is the lack of digital literacy among students, teachers, and parents. A study on the challenges of mobile learning in developing countries emphasizes that digital literacy is a critical factor in the successful adoption of mobile learning technologies [11]. Without adequate training and support, students and educators may struggle to utilize mobile learning platforms effectively, limiting their potential impact.

Another challenge is the need for robust and reliable internet connectivity. While mobile devices are widely available, the quality and availability of internet access can vary significantly across different regions. A study on the role of mobile learning in developing countries highlights that inconsistent internet connectivity can hinder the effectiveness of mobile learning platforms, as students may face difficulties accessing online resources or participating in interactive learning activities [60]. This underscores the need for investments in digital infrastructure to ensure that mobile learning platforms can function optimally.

Despite these challenges, the potential of mobile learning and m-learning platforms to transform education in developing countries is substantial. A study on the impact of mobile learning in Afghanistan provides a compelling case for the effectiveness of mobile learning in improving educational outcomes [11]. The study highlights that mobile learning can provide students with access to high-quality educational content, even in areas with limited resources. This is particularly important in regions where traditional educational infrastructure is insufficient or inaccessible.

In conclusion, mobile learning and m-learning platforms play a vital role in delivering education in resource-constrained environments. Their accessibility, convenience, and potential to enhance student engagement and learning outcomes make them a promising solution for addressing educational challenges in developing countries. While there are challenges to overcome, the growing body of research highlights the transformative potential of mobile learning in promoting equitable access to education and improving learning outcomes for students in underserved communities. As the use of mobile technologies continues to expand, it is essential to invest in digital infrastructure, digital literacy, and supportive policies to ensure that mobile learning can reach its full potential in enhancing educational opportunities for all.

content.heading: 3.4 Internet of Things (IoT) in Smart Education
content.content:
The Internet of Things (IoT) has emerged as a transformative force in the realm of smart education, offering innovative solutions to enhance classroom interactions, monitor student engagement, and improve the efficiency of educational management systems. By integrating IoT technologies into educational environments, institutions can create more dynamic and responsive learning experiences that cater to the diverse needs of students and educators alike. This subsection explores the application of IoT in smart education, highlighting its potential to revolutionize traditional educational practices.

One of the key areas where IoT is making a significant impact is in the creation of smart educational environments. These environments leverage IoT devices such as sensors, smartboards, and connected learning tools to facilitate real-time data collection and analysis. For instance, sensors embedded in classrooms can monitor environmental conditions like temperature, humidity, and noise levels, ensuring optimal learning conditions for students [24]. Such data can be used to adjust classroom settings dynamically, enhancing student comfort and focus. Moreover, smartboards and interactive displays allow for more engaging and interactive lessons, enabling educators to incorporate multimedia elements that cater to different learning styles.

Another critical application of IoT in smart education is the monitoring of student engagement. By utilizing wearable devices and IoT-enabled learning platforms, educators can track students' physical activity, attention levels, and interaction with learning materials. This data provides valuable insights into how students are engaging with the content, allowing for more personalized and adaptive teaching strategies. For example, if a student's engagement levels drop, educators can intervene promptly, offering additional support or adjusting the lesson plan to re-engage the student. This level of monitoring not only enhances the learning experience but also helps identify students who may need additional resources or interventions [61].

In addition to enhancing classroom interactions and student engagement, IoT technologies are also playing a crucial role in improving the efficiency of educational management systems. By integrating IoT devices with administrative systems, educational institutions can streamline operations, reduce manual tasks, and improve data accuracy. For instance, IoT-enabled attendance systems can automatically record student attendance, reducing the administrative burden on staff and providing real-time data for analysis. Furthermore, IoT can facilitate the tracking of student performance, enabling educators to identify trends and make data-driven decisions to support student success [62].

Moreover, IoT technologies are being used to create more inclusive and accessible educational environments. For students with disabilities, IoT can provide tailored support through assistive technologies that enhance their learning experience. For example, IoT devices can be used to create personalized learning environments that accommodate different learning needs, ensuring that all students have equal access to educational opportunities. This inclusivity is essential for fostering a supportive and equitable learning environment that caters to the diverse needs of all students [63].

The integration of IoT in education also extends to the realm of data-driven decision-making. By collecting and analyzing data from various sources, educational institutions can gain valuable insights into student performance, resource allocation, and instructional effectiveness. This data can be used to inform policy decisions, improve teaching practices, and allocate resources more effectively. For instance, data analytics can help identify areas where students are struggling, enabling educators to provide targeted support and interventions [64].

However, the implementation of IoT in education is not without its challenges. One of the primary concerns is the issue of data privacy and security. As IoT devices collect and transmit large amounts of data, it is essential to ensure that this information is protected from unauthorized access and misuse. Educational institutions must implement robust security measures and adhere to data protection regulations to safeguard student privacy [1].

Additionally, the digital divide remains a significant barrier to the widespread adoption of IoT in education, particularly in developing countries. Limited access to technology and internet connectivity can hinder the implementation of IoT solutions, exacerbating existing educational disparities. To address this, it is crucial to invest in digital infrastructure and provide training and support to educators and students to ensure that all learners can benefit from IoT-enabled educational technologies [39].

In conclusion, the integration of IoT technologies in smart education offers a wealth of opportunities to enhance classroom interactions, monitor student engagement, and improve the efficiency of educational management systems. By leveraging IoT, educational institutions can create more dynamic, inclusive, and data-driven learning environments that cater to the diverse needs of students and educators. However, addressing the challenges of data privacy, security, and the digital divide is essential to ensure that all learners can benefit from these advancements. As the field of IoT in education continues to evolve, it is imperative to prioritize equitable access and meaningful use of these technologies to support the long-term success of students and educators alike [64].

content.heading: 3.5 Use of Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) in Education
content.content:
Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) technologies have emerged as powerful tools in the field of education, offering transformative potential for enhancing experiential learning and providing immersive educational experiences. These technologies enable students to engage with complex concepts in a more interactive and dynamic manner, making learning more engaging and effective, particularly in the context of STEM education in developing countries. The integration of AR and VR in education has the potential to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application, allowing students to explore and experiment in ways that traditional methods cannot facilitate.

One of the key advantages of AR and VR in education is their ability to create immersive learning environments. For instance, in STEM education, AR and VR can simulate real-world scenarios that would otherwise be difficult or impossible to replicate in a classroom setting. Students can conduct virtual experiments, explore 3D models of complex structures, and interact with simulations that mimic real-world phenomena. This hands-on approach not only enhances understanding but also promotes critical thinking and problem-solving skills. According to a study by [50], the use of VR in education has shown promising results in improving student engagement and learning outcomes. In this study, the integration of VR into an online class allowed students to experience a more immersive and interactive learning environment, which contributed to a better understanding of the subject matter.

In developing countries, where access to physical laboratories and equipment may be limited, AR and VR technologies offer a viable solution to overcome these constraints. These technologies can provide students with access to high-quality educational resources and experiences that they might not otherwise have. For example, in the context of science education, VR can be used to simulate laboratory experiments, allowing students to conduct experiments in a safe and controlled environment. This is particularly beneficial in regions where the availability of laboratory equipment is scarce or outdated. As noted in [65], AI-driven tools, including VR, have shown potential in advancing education in Africa by providing students with access to resources and experiences that are otherwise unavailable.

Moreover, AR and VR technologies can be particularly effective in supporting the development of technical and vocational skills. These technologies can be used to create simulations that replicate real-world scenarios, enabling students to practice and refine their skills in a safe and controlled environment. This is especially relevant in fields such as engineering, medicine, and information technology, where hands-on experience is crucial. According to [66], the use of AR and VR in education has the potential to enhance the development of technical skills by providing students with opportunities to engage in practical, real-world applications of their knowledge.

The impact of AR and VR on student engagement and motivation should not be overlooked. These technologies can make learning more interactive and enjoyable, which can lead to increased student participation and a more positive attitude towards education. In a study conducted by [33], it was found that students who had access to remote learning technologies, including VR, showed higher levels of engagement and motivation compared to those who did not. This suggests that the use of AR and VR in education can have a positive impact on student performance and overall learning outcomes.

In addition to enhancing the learning experience, AR and VR technologies can also support the development of soft skills, such as collaboration, communication, and creativity. These technologies encourage students to work together, share ideas, and collaborate on projects, fostering a sense of community and teamwork. According to [67], the integration of AR and VR in education can promote the development of these essential skills by creating opportunities for students to engage in collaborative learning activities.

Despite the potential benefits of AR and VR in education, there are also challenges that need to be addressed. One of the main challenges is the lack of infrastructure and resources required to implement these technologies. In many developing countries, access to reliable internet connectivity and digital devices is limited, which can hinder the widespread adoption of AR and VR in education. According to [8], the success of educational initiatives during the pandemic was heavily dependent on the availability of digital infrastructure. This highlights the need for investments in digital infrastructure to ensure that all students, regardless of their socioeconomic background, have access to the benefits of AR and VR in education.

Another challenge is the need for teacher training and support. Educators must be equipped with the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively integrate AR and VR into their teaching practices. According to [25], the successful implementation of new technologies in education depends on the willingness and ability of teachers to adopt and utilize these tools. Therefore, it is essential to provide professional development opportunities for educators to help them navigate the complexities of integrating AR and VR into their classrooms.

In conclusion, the integration of AR and VR technologies in education offers significant potential to enhance experiential learning, provide immersive educational experiences, and support STEM education in developing countries. These technologies can help bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application, making learning more engaging and effective. However, to fully realize the benefits of AR and VR in education, it is essential to address the challenges related to infrastructure, resources, and teacher training. By investing in digital infrastructure and providing support for educators, developing countries can harness the power of AR and VR to transform their educational systems and improve learning outcomes for all students.

content.heading: 3.6 Blockchain for Secure and Transparent Education Systems
content.content:
Blockchain technology has emerged as a transformative force in various sectors, with its potential to provide secure, transparent, and tamper-proof systems. In the context of education, especially in developing countries, blockchain technology offers a promising solution to address the challenges of maintaining the security, transparency, and integrity of educational records, certifications, and digital credentials. This is particularly crucial in regions where institutional trust is limited, and there is a need for reliable and verifiable data. By leveraging the inherent properties of blockchain, such as decentralization, immutability, and transparency, educational systems can be significantly enhanced to meet the demands of a digital age.

One of the key advantages of blockchain technology in education is its ability to ensure the security of educational records. Traditional systems often rely on centralized databases, which are vulnerable to hacking, data breaches, and manipulation. In contrast, blockchain provides a decentralized ledger that is distributed across a network of computers, making it extremely difficult for any single entity to alter or manipulate the data. This ensures that educational records, such as transcripts and certifications, remain secure and unaltered. For instance, the use of blockchain for storing and verifying academic credentials can prevent fraud and ensure that students' achievements are accurately represented, which is essential in a context where trust in institutions may be low [53].

Moreover, blockchain technology enhances transparency in the educational process. By allowing all stakeholders—students, educators, and administrators—to access a shared ledger, blockchain creates a transparent environment where the flow of information is clear and accountable. This transparency is particularly beneficial in developing countries where there may be a lack of trust in educational institutions. For example, in a study conducted in Kenya, the implementation of a blockchain-based system for tracking student progress and academic achievements demonstrated the potential to improve transparency and accountability in educational outcomes [53]. The ability to track and verify educational records in real-time can foster a culture of trust and openness, encouraging students and educators to engage more actively in the learning process.

The integrity of educational credentials is another area where blockchain technology can make a significant impact. In many developing countries, the issue of forged degrees and certificates is prevalent, undermining the value of legitimate academic achievements. Blockchain can address this by providing a secure and immutable record of educational accomplishments. Each certificate or degree can be stored on the blockchain, allowing employers and other stakeholders to verify the authenticity of a candidate's credentials quickly and easily. This not only enhances the credibility of educational institutions but also ensures that students are recognized for their genuine efforts and achievements [53].

In addition to securing records and enhancing transparency, blockchain technology can also facilitate the creation of a more equitable educational system. By providing a decentralized platform for educational data, blockchain can help bridge the gap between different socioeconomic groups. For instance, students from low-income backgrounds may face challenges in accessing and verifying their educational credentials, which can hinder their opportunities for higher education and employment. Blockchain can empower these students by providing them with a secure and accessible way to store and share their credentials, thereby increasing their chances of success [53].

The application of blockchain in education is not without its challenges. One of the primary concerns is the need for digital literacy and infrastructure. In many developing countries, access to reliable internet and digital devices is limited, which can hinder the adoption of blockchain technology. Furthermore, there is a need for education and training to help educators and students understand how to use blockchain effectively. However, these challenges are not insurmountable, and with the right policies and investments, the potential benefits of blockchain in education can be realized [53].

Another important aspect of blockchain in education is the potential for innovation and new business models. By enabling the creation of decentralized educational platforms, blockchain can foster collaboration among educators, students, and institutions. This can lead to the development of new educational resources and services that are more accessible and affordable. For example, the use of blockchain for micro-credentialing allows students to earn and share smaller, more focused credentials that reflect their specific skills and knowledge, which can be particularly beneficial for those who may not have the opportunity to pursue traditional degrees [53].

Furthermore, blockchain technology can play a crucial role in addressing the challenges of remote learning, which became increasingly prevalent during the COVID-19 pandemic. The shift to online education highlighted the need for secure and reliable systems to manage student data and track academic progress. Blockchain can provide a solution by ensuring that all educational activities are recorded and verified, allowing for a seamless transition between in-person and remote learning. This can help maintain the integrity of the educational process, even in the face of unexpected disruptions [53].

In conclusion, blockchain technology has the potential to revolutionize the educational landscape, particularly in developing countries. By ensuring the security, transparency, and integrity of educational records, blockchain can help build trust in educational institutions and empower students to achieve their full potential. While there are challenges to overcome, the benefits of adopting blockchain in education are substantial and can lead to a more equitable and effective educational system. As the world continues to navigate the complexities of a digital age, the integration of blockchain into education is a promising step towards a more secure and transparent future [53].

content.heading: 3.7 Challenges in Implementing AI and Smart Technologies in Education
content.content:
The implementation of AI and smart technologies in education in developing countries presents a multifaceted challenge, encompassing infrastructure limitations, digital literacy gaps, and the need for sustainable funding and policy support. These challenges are not merely technical but deeply rooted in the socio-economic and institutional contexts of the regions where they are most needed. The adoption of AI-driven solutions and smart educational tools has the potential to revolutionize learning by offering personalized experiences, real-time feedback, and scalable solutions. However, the reality on the ground often reveals a stark contrast between the theoretical benefits and the practical barriers that hinder their deployment.

One of the primary challenges in implementing AI and smart technologies in education is the lack of adequate infrastructure. In many developing countries, the digital infrastructure necessary to support AI and smart technologies is either underdeveloped or non-existent. This includes unreliable electricity supply, poor internet connectivity, and a lack of access to the necessary hardware and software [8]. Without a stable and robust infrastructure, the deployment of AI-powered learning platforms and smart educational tools is significantly hampered. For instance, the implementation of AI-driven tutoring systems or adaptive learning platforms requires consistent internet access and reliable computing devices, which are often lacking in resource-constrained settings. This infrastructure deficit not only limits the reach of these technologies but also undermines their effectiveness, as students and educators may face frequent disruptions and technical difficulties that hinder the learning process.

Another critical challenge is the digital literacy gap among students, teachers, and parents. The successful integration of AI and smart technologies into education requires not only access to digital tools but also the skills to use them effectively. In many developing countries, a significant portion of the population lacks the necessary digital literacy to navigate online learning platforms, use AI-driven applications, or engage with smart educational tools. This digital divide exacerbates existing educational inequalities, as students from low-income families or rural areas are disproportionately affected. The lack of digital literacy is further compounded by the limited availability of training programs and educational resources that could help bridge this gap. As a result, even when AI and smart technologies are introduced, their potential to enhance learning outcomes remains unrealized due to the lack of user readiness and understanding [68].

Sustainable funding and policy support are also essential for the successful implementation of AI and smart technologies in education. The adoption of these technologies requires significant investment in infrastructure, software development, and training programs, which can be a major financial burden for resource-constrained educational institutions. Without adequate funding, the development and maintenance of AI-driven solutions and smart educational tools may be delayed or abandoned altogether. Moreover, the absence of supportive policies and regulatory frameworks can hinder the integration of these technologies into existing educational systems. Policies that promote digital inclusion, ensure data privacy, and facilitate the adoption of AI and smart technologies are crucial for creating an enabling environment for their implementation. For example, the lack of clear guidelines on data usage and security can deter educators and institutions from adopting AI-based solutions, as they may be concerned about the ethical implications and potential risks [69].

The need for policy support is further highlighted by the fact that the implementation of AI and smart technologies in education is not a one-size-fits-all solution. Different regions and educational contexts require tailored approaches that take into account local needs, cultural factors, and institutional capacities. This necessitates a collaborative effort between governments, educational institutions, and technology providers to design and implement solutions that are contextually appropriate and sustainable. For instance, the successful integration of AI-driven learning platforms in one region may not be replicable in another due to differences in infrastructure, resources, and user behavior. Therefore, policies that encourage innovation, foster collaboration, and support the development of locally relevant solutions are essential for the effective adoption of AI and smart technologies in education [70].

In addition to these structural challenges, the implementation of AI and smart technologies in education also faces resistance from educators and stakeholders who may be skeptical of the benefits or concerned about the potential displacement of traditional teaching methods. This resistance can be attributed to a lack of awareness about the capabilities of AI and smart technologies, as well as concerns about job security and the quality of education. Addressing these concerns requires comprehensive awareness campaigns, training programs, and continuous engagement with educators and stakeholders to build trust and demonstrate the value of AI and smart technologies in enhancing the learning experience. For example, the introduction of AI-driven tutoring systems or adaptive learning platforms can be more effectively accepted if educators are involved in the design and implementation process, and if they are provided with the necessary training and support to use these tools effectively [70].

In conclusion, the implementation of AI and smart technologies in education in developing countries is a complex and multifaceted challenge that requires a holistic approach. Addressing the infrastructure limitations, digital literacy gaps, and the need for sustainable funding and policy support is essential for the successful adoption of these technologies. Only through a coordinated effort that involves governments, educational institutions, and technology providers can the potential of AI and smart technologies in education be fully realized, ensuring that all students have access to high-quality, equitable, and inclusive learning opportunities.

content.heading: 3.8 Case Studies of AI and Technological Innovations in Developing Countries
content.content:
Case studies of AI and technological innovations in education across developing countries demonstrate the transformative potential of these tools in addressing educational disparities and improving access, quality, and engagement in learning. These studies highlight both the successes and the challenges of implementing such technologies in resource-constrained environments, offering valuable insights into their scalability and effectiveness.

In India, the use of mobile learning (m-learning) has emerged as a key strategy for addressing educational gaps, particularly in rural and underserved areas. A case study on the implementation of mobile learning platforms in India, such as the "Smart Kids" initiative, shows how mobile technology can be leveraged to deliver educational content to students who lack access to traditional classroom settings [71]. The initiative utilized mobile apps, radio, and television to ensure that students could continue their education during the pandemic. The results indicated that while mobile learning faced challenges such as limited device availability and internet connectivity, it was successful in maintaining educational continuity, especially for students in remote regions. The integration of mobile learning platforms allowed for personalized and adaptive learning experiences, which were crucial in mitigating the impact of school closures.

In Kenya, the use of AI-powered tools in education has been explored to improve learning outcomes and support teachers. The Kenyan government, in collaboration with private sector partners, launched several digital education initiatives, including the use of AI-driven tutoring systems and online learning platforms [72]. These initiatives aimed to provide students with access to high-quality educational resources, particularly in STEM subjects. For instance, AI-powered platforms such as Eneza Education and M-Shule have been instrumental in delivering personalized learning experiences, allowing students to learn at their own pace. The impact of these technologies has been significant, particularly in improving student engagement and retention. However, the success of these programs also highlights the need for robust digital infrastructure and teacher training to ensure the effective integration of AI into the educational system.

In Nigeria, the adoption of AI and mobile learning has been driven by the need to address the challenges of limited access to education, especially in rural areas. The Nigerian government, along with local and international organizations, has initiated several projects to promote the use of mobile learning technologies. One such initiative is the "Adaptive Learning Strategies" program, which aims to enhance the quality of education through the use of AI and mobile applications [47]. The program has been particularly effective in addressing the needs of students in remote communities, where traditional schooling is not feasible. By providing access to online learning materials and AI-powered tutoring, the program has helped to bridge the educational gap and improve learning outcomes. However, the scalability of these initiatives is still a challenge, as they require significant investment in digital infrastructure and teacher training.

In South Africa, the use of AI and digital technologies has been explored as a means of addressing the challenges of educational inequality and poor learning outcomes. During the pandemic, the South African government and educational institutions implemented a range of digital solutions, including the use of radio and television broadcasts to reach students in underserved areas [73]. AI-powered platforms such as eLevate and Muzuna have also been used to provide personalized learning experiences and support teachers in adapting to remote learning. These technologies have been particularly effective in improving student engagement and providing real-time feedback to educators. However, the implementation of these technologies has been hindered by factors such as limited internet access, lack of digital literacy, and inadequate funding.

In Bangladesh, the use of AI and mobile learning has been a key component of the country's response to the educational challenges posed by the pandemic. The government, in collaboration with international organizations and private sector partners, launched several initiatives to promote the use of digital technologies in education. One such initiative is the "Distance Learning Efforts" program, which has been instrumental in providing students with access to online learning platforms and mobile applications [49]. The program has been particularly effective in reaching students in remote and rural areas, where traditional schooling is not accessible. The use of AI-powered tools has also been explored to improve learning outcomes and provide personalized support to students. However, the implementation of these technologies has faced challenges such as limited device availability, internet connectivity, and digital literacy.

In Ethiopia, the use of AI and digital technologies has been explored as a means of addressing the challenges of educational access and quality. The government, in collaboration with local and international organizations, has launched several initiatives to promote the use of mobile learning and AI-powered tools in education. One such initiative is the "Community-Based Education Solutions" program, which has been instrumental in providing students with access to educational resources through radio and television broadcasts [74]. The program has been particularly effective in reaching students in remote and rural areas, where traditional schooling is not feasible. The use of AI-powered platforms has also been explored to provide personalized learning experiences and support teachers in adapting to remote learning. However, the implementation of these technologies has been hindered by factors such as limited internet access, lack of digital literacy, and inadequate funding.

In Brazil, the use of AI and digital technologies has been explored as a means of addressing the challenges of educational inequality and poor learning outcomes. The Brazilian government has launched several initiatives to promote the use of digital tools in education, including the development of online learning platforms and the integration of AI into the educational system [17]. These initiatives have been particularly effective in improving student engagement and providing real-time feedback to educators. However, the implementation of these technologies has been hindered by factors such as limited internet access, lack of digital literacy, and inadequate funding. The challenges faced by Brazil highlight the importance of addressing the digital divide and ensuring that all students have access to the necessary resources to benefit from AI and digital technologies.

Overall, the case studies of AI and technological innovations in education across developing countries highlight the potential of these tools to address educational disparities and improve access, quality, and engagement in learning. However, the successful implementation of these technologies requires a comprehensive approach that includes investment in digital infrastructure, teacher training, and policy support. The experiences of these countries provide valuable insights into the challenges and opportunities of integrating AI and digital technologies into the educational system, and they underscore the need for continued research and investment in this area. These insights also serve as a foundation for the future of educational technology, as emerging trends such as AI, IoT, and blockchain continue to shape the evolving landscape of education.

content.heading: 3.9 Future Prospects and Emerging Trends in EdTech
content.content:
The future of educational technology (EdTech) holds immense potential to transform the way we teach, learn, and engage with knowledge. Emerging trends such as artificial intelligence (AI), the Internet of Things (IoT), and blockchain are poised to redefine the educational landscape, offering innovative solutions to long-standing challenges in accessibility, equity, and effectiveness. As we look ahead, it is essential to explore the opportunities and challenges associated with these technologies and the need for continued research and investment.

Artificial intelligence is rapidly becoming a cornerstone of educational innovation. AI-powered tools are already being used to personalize learning experiences, automate administrative tasks, and provide real-time feedback to students. The potential of AI in education extends beyond these applications, as it can also help bridge the gap between students and teachers by identifying learning patterns and adapting instructional strategies accordingly [27]. For instance, AI-driven tutoring systems can analyze student performance data to provide targeted interventions, thereby improving learning outcomes. Moreover, generative AI models like ChatGPT and GPT-4 have shown promise in supporting language learning, content creation, and personalized assistance for students and educators [75]. These tools can help address the unique needs of diverse learners, making education more inclusive and accessible.

The Internet of Things (IoT) is another transformative force in education. IoT technologies can create smart educational environments that enhance classroom interactions, monitor student engagement, and improve the efficiency of educational management systems [23]. For example, IoT-enabled devices can track student attendance, monitor classroom conditions, and provide real-time data to teachers, enabling them to make informed decisions about instructional strategies. Additionally, IoT can facilitate the integration of experiential learning by enabling students to interact with virtual and augmented reality (AR/VR) environments, thereby deepening their understanding of complex concepts [76]. As the adoption of IoT in education continues to grow, it is crucial to address the challenges related to data privacy, security, and infrastructure requirements.

Blockchain technology also presents exciting opportunities for the future of education. By providing a secure, transparent, and tamper-proof ledger for educational records and digital credentials, blockchain can help ensure the integrity and authenticity of academic achievements [53]. This is particularly important in contexts where institutional trust is low, as blockchain can help mitigate issues related to fraud and forgery. Furthermore, blockchain can facilitate the secure sharing of educational data, enabling seamless collaboration between institutions and fostering a more interconnected educational ecosystem. However, the implementation of blockchain in education also raises questions about scalability, interoperability, and the need for robust governance frameworks. Continued research and investment are essential to address these challenges and harness the full potential of blockchain in education.

In addition to these technologies, the future of EdTech will likely involve a convergence of multiple innovations. For example, the integration of AI, IoT, and blockchain can create a holistic educational ecosystem that supports personalized learning, real-time monitoring, and secure data management. This convergence can also enable the development of adaptive learning platforms that respond to the dynamic needs of students and educators, thereby enhancing the overall learning experience [27]. Moreover, the use of big data analytics can provide valuable insights into student performance, helping educators to identify areas for improvement and tailor their instructional strategies accordingly [77].

The future of EdTech also requires a focus on addressing the digital divide and ensuring equitable access to educational resources. While technological advancements have the potential to enhance learning outcomes, they can also exacerbate existing inequalities if not implemented thoughtfully. For instance, the lack of access to reliable internet and digital devices remains a significant barrier for many students in developing countries [54]. Addressing these disparities will require a concerted effort from governments, educational institutions, and technology providers to invest in infrastructure and digital literacy programs. Furthermore, the development of affordable and accessible EdTech solutions is crucial to ensuring that all students, regardless of their socioeconomic background, can benefit from the opportunities offered by digital learning.

Research and investment in emerging EdTech trends are essential to driving innovation and addressing the challenges faced by educational systems. This includes funding for the development of AI-powered educational tools, the expansion of IoT infrastructure, and the exploration of blockchain-based solutions for educational records. Additionally, there is a need for interdisciplinary research that brings together experts from various fields, including computer science, education, and public policy, to develop comprehensive and sustainable solutions. Collaborative efforts between academia, industry, and government can help accelerate the adoption of innovative technologies and ensure that they are aligned with the needs of students and educators.

In conclusion, the future of EdTech is bright, with the potential to transform education through the integration of AI, IoT, and blockchain. However, realizing this potential will require continued research, investment, and collaboration. By addressing the challenges of accessibility, equity, and infrastructure, we can create a more inclusive and effective educational system that meets the needs of all learners. As we move forward, it is crucial to remain vigilant and proactive in our efforts to harness the power of technology for the betterment of education.

content.heading: 4.1 Infrastructure Limitations
content.content:
The infrastructure limitations in developing countries have been one of the most significant barriers to implementing effective remote learning during the COVID-19 pandemic. The lack of reliable and adequate infrastructure, including limited electricity supply, poor internet connectivity, and insufficient technological resources, has severely hindered the transition to digital education. These challenges have exacerbated existing educational disparities, especially in rural and low-income areas, where access to basic infrastructure is already limited.

Electricity supply is a critical component of any remote learning initiative, yet many developing countries face chronic shortages and unreliable power grids. In regions where the electrical infrastructure is underdeveloped, schools and households often experience frequent outages, making it difficult to maintain consistent access to digital devices and online learning platforms [78]. For instance, in sub-Saharan Africa, where electricity access is unevenly distributed, students and teachers are forced to rely on alternative energy sources such as generators or solar power, which are not always reliable or accessible [1]. This lack of stable electricity not only disrupts the learning process but also limits the ability of students to engage with digital content and complete assignments on time.

In addition to electricity, internet connectivity remains a major challenge for remote learning in developing countries. The World Bank estimates that nearly 3.7 billion people globally, mostly in low-income countries, remain offline, with internet penetration rates in many developing regions lagging far behind those in high-income countries [1]. In countries like India, where internet access is unevenly distributed, students in rural areas often have to rely on mobile networks, which are frequently slow and unreliable, limiting their ability to participate in online classes and access educational resources. The lack of high-speed internet infrastructure also restricts the use of data-intensive applications, such as video conferencing and streaming, which are essential for a comprehensive remote learning experience [1].

The limited availability of digital infrastructure further complicates the situation. Many students in developing countries lack access to the necessary devices, such as computers, tablets, or smartphones, which are essential for online learning [1]. In some cases, schools and educational institutions have attempted to distribute devices to students, but these efforts are often hindered by logistical challenges, financial constraints, and a lack of technical support. The absence of reliable digital infrastructure not only limits access to educational content but also creates a digital divide between students who can afford the necessary tools and those who cannot, further exacerbating educational inequalities [1].

Moreover, the lack of infrastructure extends beyond electricity and internet connectivity to include the physical and institutional infrastructure required to support remote learning. Many schools in developing countries lack the necessary facilities, such as classrooms equipped with digital tools, laboratories, and libraries, which are essential for a well-rounded education [1]. The sudden shift to remote learning has exposed the inadequacy of these institutions, as they are often unprepared to provide the necessary support for digital education. The absence of proper infrastructure not only affects the quality of education but also hampers the ability of educators to adapt to new teaching methods and technologies [1].

The challenges posed by infrastructure limitations are further compounded by the socioeconomic factors that influence access to education. In many developing countries, poverty and economic inequality are significant barriers to remote learning, as students from low-income families are less likely to have access to the necessary resources and support systems. The lack of financial resources also limits the ability of governments and educational institutions to invest in infrastructure improvements and digital education initiatives [1]. In countries like Nigeria, where the digital divide is particularly pronounced, the lack of infrastructure has made it difficult for students to keep up with their peers, leading to a decline in academic performance and increased dropout rates [1].

In addition to these challenges, the lack of infrastructure also affects the ability of teachers to deliver remote instruction effectively. Many educators in developing countries lack the necessary training and resources to adapt to digital teaching methods, which further limits the quality of remote learning [1]. The absence of reliable infrastructure not only makes it difficult for teachers to access digital tools and platforms but also hampers their ability to engage with students and provide meaningful feedback. This lack of support can lead to a decline in student engagement and motivation, further exacerbating the educational challenges faced by students in developing countries [1].

The limitations of infrastructure in developing countries highlight the urgent need for investment in digital education and the development of resilient educational systems. Governments and international organizations must prioritize the improvement of infrastructure, including the expansion of electricity access, the enhancement of internet connectivity, and the provision of digital devices and resources to support remote learning [1]. By addressing these infrastructure challenges, developing countries can ensure that all students have equal access to quality education, regardless of their geographic location or socioeconomic status. This will not only help mitigate the impact of the pandemic on education but also lay the foundation for a more equitable and sustainable educational system in the future [1].

content.heading: 4.2 Access to Digital Devices
content.content:
The lack of access to digital devices such as computers, tablets, and smartphones among students and teachers in developing countries has been one of the most significant barriers to remote learning during the COVID-19 pandemic. This issue is deeply rooted in both economic and logistical challenges, which have been exacerbated by the sudden and widespread shift to online education. The absence of these essential tools has not only hindered students' ability to participate in virtual classes but has also placed an immense burden on educators who are struggling to adapt to new pedagogical models without the necessary technological support.

In many developing countries, the digital divide is stark, with a large portion of the population lacking access to even basic internet connectivity, let alone the digital devices required for remote learning. According to a study conducted by the United Nations, schools' closures have impacted up to 99% of the student population in low and lower-middle-income countries [8]. This statistic underscores the extent of the problem, as millions of students found themselves unable to continue their education due to a lack of access to digital devices. In such contexts, the economic challenges of purchasing and maintaining these devices are compounded by the limited financial resources available to families, especially those in poverty-stricken areas.

The economic disparity is further reflected in the distribution of digital resources. While some students may have access to personal computers or smartphones, many others do not. This situation is particularly acute in rural areas, where infrastructure is often underdeveloped and access to digital devices is even more limited. A study on the impact of the pandemic on education in Colombia highlights that internet access strongly affects academic performance, with little improvement in internet/computer access reflecting better academic outcomes [33].
